title: Reece Shearsmith webchat âÂ as it happened | Stage | The Guardian
summary: that 's all from reece for today .
`` it should be difficult to get a television programme made . it certainly makes you more rigorous and stops you being lazy ''
`` steve and i write together in a room , line by line , one taking turns in typing while the other one sits and looks at their iphone in secret ''
`` in the 90s there were very few documentaries about extraordinary things - nowadays , every two minutes there 's my face has got a foot on it ''
`` the director made us do circuit training every morning , and martin mcdonagh did it with us ''
the local shop was a set that was built on marsden moor , and we burned it down at the end of the second series .
`` jeremy dyson wrote pop specifically for steve . i do n't know what that says of what jeremy thinks about steve ''

documents.title: that 's all from reece for today
text: guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 2:02pm thanks for all the questions , sorry if i did n't get to you .
but imagine the answer was just what you wanted - that is what i would have said .
jacknimrod asks : as a kid , what scared you more : dracula , the creature from the black lagoon , or davros from doctor who ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 2:01pm i think of those three , i would say the creature from the black lagoon .
dracula only frightened me afterwards , having watched one of the hammers , it was in the night in the dark that i would then consider him trying to get in at the window .
the creature was a proper monster - those dead eyes swimming through the weeds were a horrible sight .
mrjelly asks : has there ever been a character you developed but did n't use ?
looking back do you wish you had ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 2:00pm there was a character that mark and jeremy wrote that was a horror author , and we tried to get him in the third series , but it never quite worked out .
he was a very particular vein of comedy that they were pursuing , the bad horror author .
one of his books was called snails , and it was about snails taking over the world .
it was actually very funny , but we could never make him fit in the world of royston vasey .

documents.title: `` it should be difficult to get a television programme made . it certainly makes you more rigorous and stops you being lazy ''
text: tommyscot asks : would you expect that creative opportunities at the bbc will change as the current review begins to see real changes ?
what line needs to be taken ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:58pm i 've always been of the mind that it should be difficult to get a television programme made .

it certainly makes you more rigorous and stops you being lazy , but i hope it 's always recognised that there 's always room for all types of comedy , with it being such a subjective medium , and so much of it down to taste .
cfury asks : what are your memories of being in catterick ?
was it as much fun as it looked ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:56pm it was great fun to be asked by vic and bob to join them in their insanity .
i was a huge fan of their work , and it felt a real honour to be working with them .
i love the comedy of the mundane that they present so brilliantly , its sloppiness and its seeming artlessness is actually very carefully considered and precise .
i think that 's what makes them true geniuses .
galaxina asks : is it more difficult playing the role of a woman ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:54pm i have n't played a woman for a long time , but from what i remember of doing it , i was very comfortable .
some of them were completely padded - it felt like i was in a sofa .
alexcollier80 asks : inside number 9 series 2 podcast/commentary was a wonderful thing .
glad to see that you are better since it ended .
how much of that was planned , and how/when did you come about the idea of doing it ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:54pm it was planned from the start - we wanted to do the commentaries because we 've always done them for our shows .
but with dvd apparently dying out , as far as sales of our things went , we were told we could n't afford to do them officially .
so the podcast seemed a nice way of giving fans of the show some extra content .
it became its own little story , if you followed our characters - our characters had an argument that spilled over into steve killing me , it was very metatextual .
so we used it as another way of entertaining people , hopefully .

documents.title: `` steve and i write together in a room , line by line , one taking turns in typing while the other one sits and looks at their iphone in secret ''
text: biffers asks : how do you write with a partner ?
do you back and forth ?
or sit in a room together and one of you have every key left of h ?
how do you resolve disputes ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:52pm steve and i write together in a room , line by line , one taking turns in typing while the other one sits and looks at their iphone in secret .
we talk a lot before we begin writing so we 're sure of where we want to go .
some days are hard , other days it flows onto the page .
we never really have arguments , it 's more long silences when the other person wo n't back down .
and then we 'll leave it , and return to it with fresh eyes .
sweetbaboo asks do you like frogs ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:50pm in this house we do not say the f word .
riceuten64 asks : you 've worked with the cream of british comedy ( vic and bob , peter kay , simon pegg , etc ) - are there other people out there you 'd like to work with ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:50pm i have worked with most of the people i admire .
i had great fun working with steve coogan on his latest alan partridge mid morning matters - it felt a real honour to be on the receiving end of alan .
lewisdenson asks : do you ever try to appeal to kids or do you think that there 's a lower age limit for your work ?
i know you 've done horrible histories but that 's aimed at children .

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:49pm i do n't think that we 're ever thinking of children watching our programmes - they 're all too nasty and peppered with adult themes for me to be comfortable with showing even my own children .
my own children do n't know what i do - they 've never seen any of it .
but i am quite a puritanical father .
i 've only just let then watch in the night garden .
which i still think of as inappropriate and nightmare-inducing .
all i can think it there 's something inherently cartoonish about the level of grotesquery that our characters are sometimes played at , that transcends them being sinister and makes them funny .
like a man in a suit playing a clown .
i 've played a lot of clowns , and children do n't find them as terrifying as adults .

documents.title: `` in the 90s there were very few documentaries about extraordinary things - nowadays , every two minutes there 's my face has got a foot on it ''
text: id5252799 asks : what were the main comedic influences that led to the league of gentlemen ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:45pm our influences were more drama and documentary that comedy .
we were always big fans of actors who could do comedy like leonard rossiter , peter sellers , ronnie barker , but equally very fond of alan bennett and victoria wood .
in the 90s there were very few documentaries about extraordinary things - nowadays , every two minutes there 's my face has got a foot on it , or something .
it was slim back then , but we would mine what there was for extraordinary detail .
a lot of the barbara character came from the documentary - it 's all very un pc now because it 's transgender-phobic - but the george/julia documentaries about sex changes .
we would watch a lot of first tuesdays and dispatches , these old tv shows that would have a subject or character that might have legs .
we 're big fans of anthology shows like tales of the unexpected , hammer house of horror , and play for todays .

where you tell a story and have characters that you care about , and i think that informed our writing style , because we would try to give our sketch show characters a third dimension you might not normally expect in a comedy show .
acatcalledanarchy asks : the tent scene in a field in england is the most terrifying thing i have ever witnessed .
will you be appearing in any further movies ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:41pm yes , i appear in ben wheatley 's next film , which is called high rise .
i think it 's in cinemas early next year .
and is based on the jg ballard novel .
it 's very violent and very 70s and stars tom hiddleston .
it was great to work on - very claustrophobic , set in this modern block of flats that descends into hell as the residents and their humanity breaks down .
it 's lord of the flies in a tower block .
it 's really good - they 're showing it at the london film festival on the 9th october if you want to see a preview .
it 's very ballard and it 's very ben .
philipphilip99 asks : would the league of gentlemen team take over doctor who in its entirety if you were asked ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:39pm i think we 'll leave doctor who to mark for now .
we 've all played a little part in it now , but i think it would get too strange if characters from roysten vasey began challenging the doctor for world domination .
we 've been meeting up and talking about doing something with the league for the anniversary of it - in 2019 it 'll be 20 years since we did it .
so that might be the time to reform to do something .
mike gardner asks : i loved the episodes in inside number 9 where there was almost no talking and the episode filmed in two takes .
were these more challenging and did you do it for that reason ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:37pm yes and yes .
the silent episode on number 9 was very difficult to write , looks like nothing is happening to watch , but is very difficult to tell a story with no words .
and maintain the viewer 's attention .
and the two take episode of psychoville required lots of rehearsal , but felt a real achievement to have managed it .
could n't have done it without mark , that one .
anneclarkson asks : which is your favourite laurel and hardy film ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:35pm that 's very hard , but i love the laurel-hardy murder case .
i love the `` old dark house '' feel about it , the reading of the will at midnight , and the fact that these two are at the heart of a horror story .
it 's a very fond pairing of two things i love : comedy and horror .

documents.title: `` the director made us do circuit training every morning , and martin mcdonagh did it with us ''
text: peterjosephmck asks : my wife and i are thinking of going to hadfield for a long weekend can you recommend any good places to eat or drink ?
also , i understand martin mcdonagh was present during rehearsals for hangmen inspirational or nerve-racking ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:33pm i 'm not sure hadfield exists any more .
i think the art department destroyed it after we left in 2003 .
martin was indeed present , and a fantastic person to have in the room .
totally supportive , and willing to try anything to get the best results to render his world on stage .
the director made us do circuit training every morning , and martin did it with us .
warmed up completely - he had us going round three times by the end , it was exhausting .
but i quite miss it when we do n't do it .
applewormappleworm asks : if you had to subject yourself to one form of medieval torture , which would it be ?
the spanish donkey maybe guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:31pm if i could get a choice it would be death by mau mau .
adam duxbury asks : sometimes it feels like there 's an overwhelming amount of good tv on offer how do you decide what to watch and still have time for things like work and brushing your teeth ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:30pm i do n't watch any of it , i 'm very far behind .
i have hundreds of cellophane-wrapped box sets which i have never attempted .
i do n't know how many more hours i have left .
i really liked the comeback , the lisa kudrow series , i found that brilliant .
and hannibal - i loved that series .
the reimagining of those characters was such a beautiful execution by bryan fuller .
guidoss asks : do you consider yourself very kind , kind or not at all kind to animals ?
we do have to take your first answer .
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:29pm kind .
janneywren asks : as a young person what were your dreams , did school hinder or help them ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:28pm i was told at school by the careers advisor , when i told him i wanted to be an actor , did i not fancy a nice job in a factory ?
so in some ways it was a hindrance , but in some ways it made me more determined .
i was more interested in art when i was younger but tried acting because i felt like i would always regret not having a go .
gilesjuk asks : your league of gentlemen series featured a number of references to scenes from classic and cult films which you managed to weave into the story .
which one were you most proud of ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:27pm the denton twins are clearly a homage to the shining twins , the girls in the shining .
and in series three we use some of do n't look now , which is slightly more obscure but there for the eagle-eyed .
it was one of our favourite films - we wanted to pay homage to it .
but there are some more obscure references that are in there - the colouring of some of the episodes .
a lot of series three is sickly green , which is taken from 10 rillington place .
there 's a horrible hue to the whole thing , and we wanted that look for some of the sketches .
turk thrust asks : would you put your penis into a dead pigs mouth ( purely for artistic reasons of course ) ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:24pm how long for ?
define your terms .

documents.title: `` jeremy dyson wrote pop specifically for steve . i do n't know what that says of what jeremy thinks about steve ''
text: shevadnadze asks : pop from tlog must be one of your most unsettling and disturbing characters .
not only does he look a bit like fred west , but he seems to share one or two personality traits with him as well .
is this a coincidence and is he based on someone that you or your co-writers had actually met ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:24pm it was n't one of my characters , it was steve pemberton 's !
jeremy dyson wrote pop specifically for steve , as steve asked him to write him a character .
i do n't know what that says of what jeremy thinks about steve .
but certainly not based on fred west - it 's based on steve pemberton .
meryn davies asks : do you prefer acting live in the theatre , or on camera , and do you find one more difficult than the other ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:23pm when i am in the middle of doing one i begin to crave the other .
both are equally challenging , in theatre you get the rare opportunity of having another go , night after night , and exploring far more deeply the character you 're playing .
acting on camera is much more disposable and yet stays around for all to see for years after .
that 's the magic of theatre , that it 's a nightly event that you have to be there to experience .

even last night i was talking to johnny flynn that it was the best we 'd done it , and we 've been doing it for two weeks - something new came out of the scene that was n't there before , and that 's constantly happening when you 're travelling through a character 's journey through a story .
mrmitchell78 asks : when you part of a big success such as league of gentlemen , does it at some point become a hindrance or has it done nothing but opened doors for your subsequent projects ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:20pm i 'm very proud of the league of gentlemen , and it 's been the reason i 've had any life in acting subsequently .
it opened every door , and became the thing that we were known for , and made it much easier to be thought of for subsequent acting roles .
so it was everything to have decided to do our own thing .
we all tried to be actors individually , and pretty much failed .
it was n't until that , that anyone knew who we were .
jen ashworth asks : why are you so grumpy ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:19pm because of you .
i 'm only grumpy when i 'm asked if i 'm grumpy - then i become grumpy .
brookerfan asks : how do you find working with jimmy and sean on countdown does 9/10 cats ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:18pm you have mistaken me for another northern man with black hair .
or they know full well and they 're being devilish .
katemk21 asks : i am currently rewatching the third series of the league of gentlemen , which still seems so bold and inventive nearly 15 years after it was first on .
did you realise when making the show what a lasting appeal and impact it would have ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:18pm no , we had no idea that it would have such longevity , pleased that our sense of humour translated and found an audience .
you can never predict what will catch fire in people 's imaginations .
but we knew that it was full of detail , and that it would bear repeated viewing .
so i think that 's why it does n't feel too dated , even now .
it 's kind of like science fiction , it feels like its own world - and was never part of our world .
so that 's why it does n't feel like it was locked in the 90s , particularly .
tulsablackwell asks : would you ever write a play that you did n't have an acting role in ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:16pm i 'm only interested in writing things that i 'll be in .
i do n't really consider myself a writer for hire .
ca n't see the point of creating parts for other actors .
i find it a means to an end , writing - it would be madness to hand over a script and not being involved from that point onwards .

i must have half an eye on writing characters that i think i 'll be able to do , otherwise i 'd be a hindrance to myself - but it is nice , with the number 9s , to write good parts for people , and then hopefully you can attract good actors .
we all know what it 's like to receive a call for a part , and there be even one sentence that makes it worth doing .
we like to put those little nuggets in , to trap people into saying yes .
revengekitten asks : has the bbc given you and steve any indication yet for a 3rd series of the outstanding inside no 9 ' ?
are you currently writing anything together at the moment ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:13pm we are writing together at the moment , on a secret project which will be revealed shortly but we 're very honoured to be asked to write it .
alocin42 asks : do you find yourself often offered roles where the characters are a bit creepy or weird , and how do you feel about being associated with that sort of part ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:13pm yes and no .
i 'm either offered the psychopath or the everyman , and i do n't mind playing either , if i feel i can bring something to the role .
christine robinson asks : seeing recently you have a part in dr who , how did it feel to be asked to do a part in our greatest sci-fi programme ever ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:12pm it was a great honour to be asked by mark to ( finally ) be in doctor who .
he 's been saying for a long time he 'll write me a part , so it was nice when it finally happened .
it was great to find myself talking to the doctor , and calling him the doctor , and i really felt like i was properly in that world .
it felt very special .
ejihh2 asks : what is it that the silent singer is miming ?
is it an actual song , and if so does it hold any significance ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:11pm the silent singer is miming an actual song , but it is so obscure it would be difficult for me to explain what it is or where it comes from .
so i 'm not going to .
matt andy bevan asks : would you ever be interested in directing a film ?
if so , which genre ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:10pm i would be interested in directing a film - it would be horror of course , or a ghost story , or a haunted house story .
i think it would be quite self-contained and claustrophobic , with a team of characters sent there to investigate the haunting .
drgonzo123 asks : when working in partnerships , have you ever fought over who gets to play a character ?
if they won , do you still reckon you would of done it better ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:09pm we do n't write the parts for ourselves , so that we service the telling of the story first and foremost .
it 's only after that we decide who plays who , and sometimes we 've chosen the parts that are n't necessarily best suited to us , but that 's part of keeping it fresh for ourselves .
a case in point would be in cold comfort , the episode of inside number 9 - it could easily have been that steve was the boss and i was the new recruit .
we had it that way round , but we swapped it , because we thought it would be more interesting having steve as the green , fresh faced recruit .
it was n't a stretch , but it was n't the way we subconsciously imagined it happening .
mezzamorta asks : hi reece - congratulations on hangmen .
went on saturday and loved it .
i saw the screening of 10 rillington place you introduced last year , one of my favourite films .
if you could curate a night at the theatre , what play/plays would you show ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:07pm i would like to show eugene ionesco plays as i 've always found him surreal and funny and creepy and dark - all the things i 'm attracted to .

they 're an untraceable thing from when i was little - i was always interested in spooky things , ghosts , the unknown , and this carried on right through my childhood and i try to feed it into my work .
it would appeal to me to see those plays , because they 're not done enough .
karen samways asks : reece , what would you say has been your most favourite performance you have performed , to date ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:05pm my favourite play was art , the yasmina reza play that i was in with mark and steve in 2003 .
it 's a brilliant play , and it was fun to act in a kind of semi-serious/comic world with those two , it 's just a joy to spend any time with them .
we were the last cast of art on the west end , and i really enjoyed it .

andrew adam says : it 's a pity no-one seems to be able to get the awful canned laughter that was added to the league of gentlemen first series in particular , that was absent in the first broadcast of it .
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:04pm incorrect !
league of gentlemen always had laughter on it - you just did n't hear it the first time round because you were laughing yourself .
why would you ever add it later ?

documents.title: the local shop was a set that was built on marsden moor , and we burned it down at the end of the second series
text: mfstigerbattles asks : i live in hadfield and i 'm totally stumped , where was tubbs ' shop filmed ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:03pm the local shop was a set that was built on marsden moor , and we burned it down at the end of the second series .
a three-sided set - a huge edifice .
very sturdy .
i think there are pilgrimages even today to go and collect bits of burned wood that was the local shop .
naomiroseamy asks : has writing for and starring in tv and film left watching it a bit lacklustre ?
has it spoiled the magic , and do you ever think , i can play dead better than that ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:02pm i do n't think `` i can play dead better than that '' , but i do think about the nuts and bolts of the edit , and the process of making tv , that you simply would n't if you were not in it .
and that does sometimes take away from purely enjoying something in the moment .
but i am able to be transported .
francolfc asks : looking back , is there a character of yours in the league of gentlemen which you feel did n't quite work ?
if so , who & why ?
and thanks for the gift that was papa lazarou .
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:01pm i felt like we did n't do enough of dean tavalouris - it 's exactly the same name as the editor in the godfather .
he was the amateur , bad magician that lived with his mum .
nick510 asks : what was your inspiration for the acting in the scene exiting the alchemist 's tent in a field in england ' ?

guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 1:00pm i was thinking very specifically of the part in the evil dead when they have the girl in the cellar , and she 's smiling and peeping out of the trap door .
and it was that euphoric , leering grin i was drawn to as i left the tent .
i thought it would be a strange choice , having just been screaming , to come out euphoric and happy .
melodyjs asks : how has your acting style developed from being a university graduate to now ?
do you feel that it has changed or stayed the same ?
also any tips on starting out acting in the theatre ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:59pm hopefully i have got a bit subtler , but more confident .
i was quite aware of an audience when i was younger and on stage , but i think i have overcome that meekness .
i feel a bit more assured .
it 's the doing of it - you only learn by doing really , and having had lots of practice , you get more and more confident if what it will feel like being in front of people .
that 's specifically stage , but the same goes for being in front of the camera too .
liam quane asks : what was it like working with ben wheatley ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:57pm ben is a fantastic director - very sure of what he wants , and makes you better as an actor .
which is all you really want from a director .
he comes up and will give you a suggestion to try it in a way you might not have thought of , so you do n't do the bag of tricks you might call upon more easily as a first thought .
mark mclauchlan asks : is it true that royston vasey was supposed to be hull ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:56pm no - royston vasey was supposed to be royston vasey it 's an amalgam of hull , chorley , leeds and newton aycliffe .
it 's our collective memory of northern life .
monkeypuzzletree asks : i really enjoyed your readings of robert aickman 's stories .
do you have a favourite ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:54pm ringing the changes .
the dead come back to life - it 's one of the creepiest ones he has written i think .
jend001 asks : what will you do on hallowe'en ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:54pm what i do on halloween is a closely guarded secret .
eµææ´ asks : mr lazarou , can i be your real wife guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:53pm no .
i have enough now .
mysterycaller asks : 7 .
what do you enjoy most while filming ?
guardian contributor reeceshearsmith1 23 september 2015 12:52pm to number 7 - being brought constant cups of tea .

documents.title: reece is with us at guardian towers !
text: reece shearsmith at the guardian offices beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for reece shearsmith
text: you 're my wife now !

with this simultaneously hilarious and blood-chilling line , reece shearsmith wormed his way into the zeitgeist as sinister ringmaster papa lazarou just one of the many characters in bizarro sitcom the league of gentlemen .
after further freaking out the genre with psychoville , shearsmith has since expanded into a wide variety of roles .

on tv there 's crowdpleasing fare like itv drama the widower and the current series of doctor who ; on film he 's starred in ben wheatley 's psychotropic civil war drama a field in england , and will appear in his jg ballard adaptation high rise .
and beginning this week , he takes a lead role in hangmen , the new play by martin mcdonagh , in a performance described as pitch-perfect by the guardian 's michael billington .

as hangmen opens at the royal court , reece will take on your questions in a live webchat on wednesday 23 september from 1pm bst onwards post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: The League of Gentleman actor who is currently appearing in new play Hangmen answered your questions at 1pm on Wednesday 23 September, giving his insights into lost characters, creative influences and his comedy writing technique. Read his responses below.
